xxl.core.math.statistics.nonparametric.kernels
Class AbstractKernelCDF

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.functions.Function<Number,Double>
      xxl.core.math.functions.AbstractRealFunctionFunction
          xxl.core.math.statistics.nonparametric.kernels.AbstractKernelCDF
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, RealFunction, WindowQuery
Direct Known Subclasses:
HybridKernelCDF, NativeKernelCDF, ReflectionKernelCDF
public abstract class AbstractKernelCDF
extends AbstractRealFunctionFunction
implements WindowQuery

One main problem of nonparametric statistics is the estimation of the probability density function (pdf) of a random variable. The estimation typically relies on a given sample, in our case data given by objects of type Number. For density estimation kernel based techniques are quite robust and useful. There, for each data point X_i a kernel is centered at X_i. Then, the sum is built over all kernels. The kernel density estimator inherits the basic properties of the kernel function. For this function different choices are possible whereas a pdf is advisable (that is restricted to [-1,1] in our case). The mostly used kernels are positive and symmetric with a compact support, e.g., the Epanechnikow kernel or the Gaussian kernel. The choice of the bandwidth h, which controls the degree of smoothness, is crucial for the quality of the estimation. There is a trade-off in choosing the bandwidth. If h is too high, the resulting estimate is smooth and may hide local features of the density. For a small bandwidth, the estimate will be spiky and artificial artifacts may be introduced.
If the primitive of the kernel is known, this approach can be extended towards the estimation of the cumulative distribution function (cdf) by simply integrating the kernel based density estimator appropriately. Picking up this idea, this class provides a skeleton implementation of a kernel based estimator for the cdf.
The estimator itself extends AbstractRealFunctionFunction. Thus, it is implemented as a one-dimensional function expecting objects of type Number as well as a RealFunction expecting data of type double. Estimators for the cdf provide estimations of the probability and in the database context this is applicable for selectivity estimation. Concerning this regard, WindowQuery is implemented.
Since this class provides a preimplementation, it is abstract and implementing classes only need to implement the methods evalKDE(double x) and windowQuery(Object left, Object right). Note: A sample of any kind of data given by an iterator could be easily obtained through the reservoir sampler cursor.
Generally, a more detailed coverage of kernel based density estimation respectively cdf estimation is given in [Sco92]: David W. Scott. Multivariate Density Estimation: Theory, Practice, and Visualization. 1992.

See Also:
Function, KernelFunction, KernelBandwidths, AbstractRealFunctionFunction, NativeKernelCDF, ReflectionKernelCDF, Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

AbstractKernelCDF

public AbstractKernelCDF(KernelFunction kf,
                         Object[] sample,
                         double h)
                  throws IllegalArgumentException
Gives a skeleton implementation for a kernel based cdf estimator.

Parameters:
kf - used Kernel function with support restricted to [-1,1]
sample - sample of a data set given as Object[] containing objects of type Number.
h - used bandwidth for computing the estimation
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if a kernel function without restricted support to [-1,1] is given or a kernel function is given that doesn't implement the interface Integrable
